CIVIL ENGINEERS RETURN
Five Hopkins Students Visited Norfolk,
Newport News and Portsmouth on
Tour of Inspection.

The civil engineering trip to
Norfolk turned out to be the
most instructive and interesting
trip that the senior engineers had
made so far. They returned to
Baltimore with a fair impression
of what twentieth century engineers are accomplishing. They
will not soon forget the practical
object lessons they learned from
seeing from first hand sources
such massive structures as were
shown them during their brief
stay on Monday and Tuesday,
April 28 and 29.
The party, which consisted of
Professor J. H. Bringhurst, C. H.
Baxley, C. E. Keefer, C. W.
Schmidt, H. W. Taylor and J. K.
Vickers, was met by Vice-Admiral
Harris, .one of our greatest authorities on port construction,
who detailed Lieutenant Holliday
to conduct the party in his own
private speed boat.
The first point of interest to
be visited was Portsmouth, just
across the Elizabeth river, opposite Norfolk. There they saw
structures that many practicing
engineers have never had the op
portunity to see. The colossal
150 ton crane, the second largest
in the world, the largest dry dock
in the world, and the giant 2,000ton compressor, were inspected by
the Hopkins men with great interest,
At the army and the navy
bases they were equally recompensed with sights of worldwide interest. The permanent
army base covers nine hundred
acres of land, has forty miles of
railroad track and an equal
amount of concrete roads. The
freight facilities for bringing cars
into the yards are highly efficient.
The two famous piers, the largest
in the world, and the store houses
1,600 feet long, added to the collection of sights.
While on this tour of inspec
tion, the party saw a "flock" of
hydroplanes and one dirigible.
The former host of planes performed all sorts of stunts and
were an unexpected diversion to
the visitors.
The large rolling lift span of
the bridge between Berkley and
Norfolk WaS of particularly instructive value.
On Tuesday Professor Bringhurst and his men went to the
Newport News navy yard where
the features of the 75-ton crane
were explained to them. While
they were there they went through
the eleven large shipways where
torpedo boat destroyers were
constructed and saw by illustration how the floating gate functioned in the dry-docking of a
ship.

MANUFACTURERS OF

HIGH GRADE CHOCOLATES.

The "R. 0. T. C. Exchange" is
still receiving letters of congratulation and promises of hearty
support from headquarters and
from commandants of units in all
parts of the country. Captain
Guild has asked for the assistance
of any of the students who are
qualified and who can give the
necessary time. The editors of
the .NEws-LETTER have been particularly invited to become assist
ant editors of the "Exchange."
Word has been received that
the R. 0. T. C. summer camp will
begin June 21, and will last six
weeks. The students from Johns
Hopkins will go to Camp Lee, receiving their transportation from
Baltimore to that place free.
Those attending will receive uniforms and subsistance. About
fifteen have already signed up.

A large number of the students
of the Engineering Department
were present at the J. E. Aldred
Lecture on April 30th. The lecturer was Mr. P. H. Falter, of
the Shawinigan Electro-Products
Company of Baltimore, who
spoke on "The Production of
Fifty Per Cent. Ferro-Silicon."
The speaker first described the
raw material used in the process.
The iron must be low in sulphur,
phosphorus and calcium, mainly
on account of the gases given off.
The proportions of the raw materials must be carefully considered.
The charge, of iron and silicon
rock, is crushed and cindered,
and then fed into the furnace
from above.
The sides of the furnaces are
of brick, and the bottoms of large
blocks of carbon. The carbon
electrodes, which produce the
electric arc in the furnace, are in
groups of three, covered with a'
plaster-like coating to protect
them from the intense heat, and
containing sets of pipes for
water-cooling. A power hoist
lowers them into the charge and
removes them at the end of a run.
On account of the low voltage and
correspondingly high currents,
the conductors from the transformers must be very- large in
Among the problems of operation, the lecturer mentioned the
minimizi,ng of costs, the ways of
working in the intense heat and
glare, the close attention to the
operation of the arc, and the prevention of the burning of the
carbons. A number of slides were
shown, giving views of the charging floor and of the electrodes.
A most interesting slide was the
diagram of the arrangement of
all of the apparatus of..the plant.

An Un-American Union.

The communication that graces
the military bulletin board from
the "American Union Against
Militarism" should prove obnoxious to all red-blooded Americans.
The very first sentence of this
propagandist literature, which
states that the "Union" has been
conducting a four-year fight,
should be enough to disgust the
f. reader.
From our very capital, this
group of misguided individuals
has carried on operations against
"militarism" since long before
our entry into the war. They
were of the type that did all they
could to hinder the nation's preparation for and conduct of the
war; and now, taking advantage
of the reaction caused by cessation of hostilities, and too shortsighted to see any impending
danger, they would render us defenseless. '
"College men and women who
want America to keep faith with
the world and work toward disarmament, are cordially invited
to enroll as college members of
the 'American Union Against Mil-

itarism' iii the tight against compulsory in ilita ry training and
service. From its headquarters,
203 Westory building, Washing
ton, D. C., the Union conducts its
tight in Congress; it furnishes a
confidential bulletin service to all
its members; it provides material
for debaters; it maintains a
strong press bureau which sends
matter to a growing list of daily
and weekly newspapers now totaling more than 900."
So runs part of the prelude of
the communication, the body of
which is composed of a rather
poor variety of jokes at the expense of the S. A. T. C., which
they so originally term "Sad and
Terrible Calamity." It is certainly true that the workings of
the S. A. T. C., especially after
armistice signing, were in many
respects quite defective, and all
were glad when the sheepskins
were distributed. The attacks of
the "Union" instead of being
sensible criticism, however, are
confined to a page of utterly foolish banter.
In answer to the enrollment
card, which reads "Gentlemen:
What I know about Compulsory
Military Training is plenty,—enroll me as a member. Here's my
contribution," one college has
did not like the
answered.
working of the S. A. T. C., but
we like this less."
An expression of opposition is
being signed by many Hopkins
men at the post office, and a protest was voiced at Friday's mass
At first sight the
meeting.
"Union" appears to be unworthy
even of such notice—an organization whose literature should
promptly be consigned to the
basket. When we consider, however, that it has operated for four
years, is active in Congress, furnishes a confidential bulletin service to members, and maintains
a strong press bureau, we can see
a menace to the safety of our
country. It would be well then
for colleges—and several have already done so—to make a signed
demonstration that no such
propaganda can gain ground
among American college men.

STUDENTS OBJECT TO "AMERICAN
UNION AGAINST MILITARISM."

A very enthusiastic mass meeting was held in the Civil Engineering hall on Friday, May 2.
The meeting was opened by a
short talk by Harris Kirk, president of the student council, who
explained the action which the
council had taken to discourage
the spreading of the propaganda
of the American Union Against
Militarism, which has been so
freely distributed among the colleges and universities of this country. The object of this "Union" is
to abolish all forms of military
training, especially the R. 0. T. C.
The purpose of and forces behind
such a movement as this are
plainly Bolshevik. After a few
words from Captain Guild, the
following protest against the
Union was unanimously adopted:
To the War Department:
The undersigned students of
this University desire to express
their disapproval of the activities of the "American Union
Against Militarism," as expressed
by the pamphlets and post cards
sent out by this "Union."
A copy of this protest is now
at the University post-office, and
all students are urged to sign it
at once.
Announcements were then made
by the Dramatic Club and other
organizations, and the meeting
was closed by a number of peppy
yells and songs, led by the newly
elected leaders, Townsend and
Lovell.

Urges Greater Support for Teams.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir:—Now that the baseball
season is in full sway it seems
to me that more attention should
be called to the cheering. Nearly
one half of the under-graduate
students appear to have the idea
that attending this university involves. nothing more than applying themselves to their various

courses. I do not mean to insinuate that this is not by far
their most important duty, but at
the same time I wish to emphasize that it is up to every student to be out for some college
activity.
If you can't make the team, at
least come out and root for it.
Give it the benefit of all the "pep"
and enthusiasm that is in you.
Let it know that there is a• big
crowd of followers in the stand
watching its every movement, and
let it know it by the noise you
make. At all our games this
year we have had a fair number
of rooters on hand, but there
ought to have been twice as many
and I want to take this opportunity to urge every man to come
out for every game and cheer his
team to victory.

ROOTER.

117th VICTIM OF 'VARSITY NINE

MURPHY ADDRESSES STUDENTS

Mortarmen Give Black and Blue a Scare
but Fail to Hit Judefind —Littman,
Sharretts, E. Jones, and Judefind
Star with Willow for Hopkins.

Coach Tells How Recent Athletic
Achievements of J. H. U. Teams Have
Paved Way for Bigger Athletic Relations-Freshmen to carry Banner.

Coming up from behind, the
baseball team nosed out the 117th
Trench Mortar Battery, 9-8.
Calkins, a new addition to the
squad, started the game on the
peak, but proved to be unsteady,
and was yanked after four runs
had been scored in the fourth.
Judefind was sent in to carry on
the twirling, and allowed only
three scattered hits.
In the meantime the Black and
Blue batters had no difficulty in
solving Wasserman's delivery,
hitting the ball at will and scoring in every session but one. The
Battery started off with a jump,
denting the rubber three times in
the first session on four passes
and three errors. The 'Varsity
came back at them with a like
number of counters in its turn.
Benson was out, Gerwig to
Wright. Littman singled to left
and Sharretts knocked a grounder
to short that was too hot to handle. Kolhep then made a wild
heave to first, and Littman
crossed the plate. Knecht sacrificed Sharretts to third, the latter
scoring on a wild throw by the
second baseman.
Bloomsburg
walked, stole second and counted
when Yarnell dropped Jack Jones'
fly.
A pass, an error, and three
triples accounted for a quartet
of tallies garnered by the mortarmen in the fourth. Hopkins
tied the count in the sixth, but
the overseas men forged ahead in
the seventh on a single, a pass
and an error. Iii the last half
Elmer Jones led off with a double to left, but hurt his foot, so
Webb was sent in to run for
him. Egerton flied to Wright.
Then Judefind came to bat and
won his own game by singling to
right, driving Webb in with the
tying count, and scoring a moment later on Sharretts' single.
The score:

A mass meeting was called on
April 29, 1919, before the baseball game with the 117th Trench
Mortar Battery. In spite of the
short notice given, the meeting
was well attended, and was
marked by announcements of
general interest to Hopkins students.
Harris Kirk started things by
urging everyone to attend the
game in the afternoon, and announced that there would be a
mass meeting every Friday, at 1
o'clock, at which everyone was expected to be present—no exceptions.
Coach Murphy then said that
he wanted to see the Trench Mortarmen given a good reception at
Homewood Field. Charlie Leber
led some Hopkins songs and yells
which were delivered with the
same old pep. Then a call for
volunteers went forth — volunteers to carry in the 117th's
parade the banner announcing
the game, and now it was that
our fine sense of modesty was
displayed. Call after call for
courageous volunteers was made
but still the bashful boys hung
back. It was even hinted that
a selective service act would have
to be put into action and the required number drafted from the
freshman. Finally four brave
youths of '22 stood up and the
danger was over.
The meeting wound up with an
interesting announcement by Mr.
Murphy. This was about the
University's entrance into big
league relations. During its
northern trip, the baseball team
defeated Columbia, whose team
in turn trounced Princeton.
This, of course, made a good
impression on some of the larger
universities. Moreover, at the
Penn Relays in Philadelphia, the
J. H. U. track men carried off a
banner and broke a record. At
this meet teams from three Baltimore institutions won their
events. This made an even better impression. The Penn Relays are considered the most important track event of the year,
and the scoring of so signal a
success gave everyone an oppor
tunity to realize that Baltimore
was on the map. Next year
Howard will i come to Baltimore
to play Hopkins.

VIRGINIA AWARDED DECISION
University of Virginia Downs Hopkins
Debaters by Vote of 2-1—Rebuttal
Speeches Fast and Furious-Hopkins
Entertained at Charlottesville.

You may hunt the
world over—but you cannot find a cigarette to
take the place of Murad.
The tobacco in Murad is 100% pure

"Judge for yourself

At Charlottesville the Black
and Blue team was defeated by
the Virginia affirmative, the
judges voting two to one in favor
of the latter. Messrs. Foster and
Lavenstein, the'Virginia debaters,
were forced to go full steam the
whole way; for it was one of the
closest debates the triangle has
had. It was give and take from
start to finish; the rebuttals
ended up in a veritable whirlwind on each side.
The Hopkins team was shown
all the attentions and courtesies
which the Charlottevillians, in
true chivalrous southern style,
could shower upon them. Before
the debate, the Hopkins men were
shown the beauties of the University which Jefferson founded.
In the evening, after the contest,
an entertainment was provided,
in which debaters and audience
joined.

1Rare Instrument in Botanical Gardens.
A dendrograph has been installed on a beech tree located in
the north end of the botanical
garden back of Gilman Hall.
The dendrograph, a late invention by Dr. MacDougal of the
Desert Laboratory, Arizona, is an
instrument which records the
daily expansion and contraction
of a tree trunk. The data thus
recorded is to be used in the
study of the growth of trees.

According to a recent University notice, during the month of
May in each year all students in
residence must consult their advisers with regard to the courses
to be taken in the following
academic year, and must report
to the Registrar before June 1st.
A fine of one dollar a day will
be levied for delay in making
this report. Changes may be
made by notification to the Registrar at any time before September 24, 1919; after that date,
only with the approval of the
Dean. Students who fail to attend courses selected, or Who
drop courses without the approval of the Dean, will be
marked absent and will be subject to the regulations of the
Committee on Absences.
A
printed form is provided for the
report of courses.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 6, 1919

DR. SLONIMSKY ADDRESSES CLUB

JUNIORS ELECT HULLABALOO
EDITOR FOR NEXT YEAR.

Speaks at Second Meeting of Social
Science Club on "An Indictment
of the Present Social Order."

At a meeting of the Junior
class on May 1st it was- decided
to depart from the custom of
previous years and elect the
Editor-in-Chief of the 1920 Hullabaloo, by the vote of the class.
Millard Foard and John Bartels
were nominated for this respons
ible position, and, on the declining of the honor by the latter,
Foard was elected by acclamation.
The question as to whom the
class would invite to the Junior
banquet to represent the faculty
was likewise voted upon. After
sonic discussion, Professor Julian
C. Smallwood, beloved by all of
the engineering students, was
chosen.
The election of the other four
members of the Hullabaloo board
was postponed until the next
meeting.

At the second meeting of the
Social Science Club, Dr. Slonimsky spoke on the first of the subjects set by the club for discussion, namely, on "The Indictment of the Present Social Order." His main contention was
that the root cause of the evils
of society is not to be sought in
any one single wrong or defect,
economic or political in character,
but rather in the method underlying both, the basic method of
the present social order. This
he designated as the "jungle
method," or the method of decision through superior force, and
he pointed out that it is not
merely inhuman' but enormously
wasteful.
Dr. Slonimsky said in part:
"The method by which society
lives is one taken over from a
lower plane of life. The method
of the jungle was fitted for the
jungle, but on the human plane
it is an absurd and deadly survival, which must be replaced by
the method of intelligent co-operation.• As long as we continue to
live by it, nothing permanently
progressive can be achieved. It
gives the lie to all our professions of religion, morality and
civilization; and it cramps and
distorts human nature, and nullifies its best endeavors. Thus, under the present system even the
most well-intentioned capitalist,
the most idealistic statesman, are
condemned to futility. Should
the young capitalist go too far
in his attempts to help his employees, he would be pushed to
the wall by the ruthless competition of his next door neighbor.
Should the young statesman be
utterly free from imperialistic
greed, should he be actuated by
nothing but pure love for his own
country, he would still be compelled by the logic of circumstances to urge adequate armament in self-defense, and thus
bring on militarism and all that
it implies. The effective morality
of individuals can hardly rise
higher than that of the system in
which they live. Those who are
unwilling to work for a better
order rest their arguments upon
'human nature' and its inherent
selfishness and aggressiveness.
War and poverty would accordingly be a part of the eternal
scheme of things. That is not
merely a counsel of despair but
also one of ignorance. In the
first place, human nature is quite
as much social and altruistic as
it is selfish and domineering;
only that by our system we allow
the latter to flourish and compel
the former to wither. In the second place, human nature is not
the hard and fast entity imagined; it is a bundle of possi-

CIVIL ENGINEERS RETURN
Five Hopkins Students Visited Norfolk,
Newport News and Portsmouth on
Tour of Inspection.

The civil engineering trip to
Norfolk turned out to be the
most instructive and interesting
trip that the senior engineers had
made so far. They returned to
Baltimore with a fair impression
of what twentieth century engineers are accomplishing. They
will not soon forget the practical
object lessons they learned from
seeing from first hand sources
such massive structures as were
shown them during their brief
stay on Monday and Tuesday,
April 28 and 29.
The party, which consisted of
Professor J. H. Bringhurst, C. H.
Baxley, C. E. Keefer, C. W.
Schmidt, H. W. Taylor and J. K.
Vickers, was met by Vice-Admiral
Harris, .one of our greatest authorities on port construction,
who detailed Lieutenant Holliday
to conduct the party in his own
private speed boat.
The first point of interest to
be visited was Portsmouth, just
across the Elizabeth river, opposite Norfolk. There they saw
structures that many practicing
engineers have never had the op
portunity to see. The colossal
150 ton crane, the second largest
in the world, the largest dry dock
in the world, and the giant 2,000ton compressor, were inspected by
the Hopkins men with great interest,
At the army and the navy
bases they were equally recompensed with sights of worldwide interest. The permanent
army base covers nine hundred
acres of land, has forty miles of
railroad track and an equal
amount of concrete roads. The
freight facilities for bringing cars
into the yards are highly efficient.
The two famous piers, the largest
in the world, and the store houses
1,600 feet long, added to the collection of sights.
While on this tour of inspec
tion, the party saw a "flock" of
hydroplanes and one dirigible.
The former host of planes performed all sorts of stunts and
were an unexpected diversion to
the visitors.
The large rolling lift span of
the bridge between Berkley and
Norfolk WaS of particularly instructive value.
On Tuesday Professor Bringhurst and his men went to the
Newport News navy yard where
the features of the 75-ton crane
were explained to them. While
they were there they went through
the eleven large shipways where
torpedo boat destroyers were
constructed and saw by illustration how the floating gate functioned in the dry-docking of a
ship.

A large number of the students
of the Engineering Department
were present at the J. E. Aldred
Lecture on April 30th. The lecturer was Mr. P. H. Falter, of
the Shawinigan Electro-Products
Company of Baltimore, who
spoke on "The Production of
Fifty Per Cent. Ferro-Silicon."
The speaker first described the
raw material used in the process.
The iron must be low in sulphur,
phosphorus and calcium, mainly
on account of the gases given off.
The proportions of the raw materials must be carefully considered.
The charge, of iron and silicon
rock, is crushed and cindered,
and then fed into the furnace
from above.
The sides of the furnaces are
of brick, and the bottoms of large
blocks of carbon. The carbon
electrodes, which produce the
electric arc in the furnace, are in
groups of three, covered with a'
plaster-like coating to protect
them from the intense heat, and
containing sets of pipes for
water-cooling. A power hoist
lowers them into the charge and
removes them at the end of a run.
On account of the low voltage and
correspondingly high currents,
the conductors from the transformers must be very- large in
Among the problems of operation, the lecturer mentioned the
minimizi,ng of costs, the ways of
working in the intense heat and
glare, the close attention to the
operation of the arc, and the prevention of the burning of the
carbons. A number of slides were
shown, giving views of the charging floor and of the electrodes.
A most interesting slide was the
diagram of the arrangement of
all of the apparatus of..the plant.

An Un-American Union.

The communication that graces
the military bulletin board from
the "American Union Against
Militarism" should prove obnoxious to all red-blooded Americans.
The very first sentence of this
propagandist literature, which
states that the "Union" has been
conducting a four-year fight,
should be enough to disgust the
f. reader.
From our very capital, this
group of misguided individuals
has carried on operations against
"militarism" since long before
our entry into the war. They
were of the type that did all they
could to hinder the nation's preparation for and conduct of the
war; and now, taking advantage
of the reaction caused by cessation of hostilities, and too shortsighted to see any impending
danger, they would render us defenseless. '
"College men and women who
want America to keep faith with
the world and work toward disarmament, are cordially invited
to enroll as college members of
the 'American Union Against Mil-

itarism' iii the tight against compulsory in ilita ry training and
service. From its headquarters,
203 Westory building, Washing
ton, D. C., the Union conducts its
tight in Congress; it furnishes a
confidential bulletin service to all
its members; it provides material
for debaters; it maintains a
strong press bureau which sends
matter to a growing list of daily
and weekly newspapers now totaling more than 900."
So runs part of the prelude of
the communication, the body of
which is composed of a rather
poor variety of jokes at the expense of the S. A. T. C., which
they so originally term "Sad and
Terrible Calamity." It is certainly true that the workings of
the S. A. T. C., especially after
armistice signing, were in many
respects quite defective, and all
were glad when the sheepskins
were distributed. The attacks of
the "Union" instead of being
sensible criticism, however, are
confined to a page of utterly foolish banter.
In answer to the enrollment
card, which reads "Gentlemen:
What I know about Compulsory
Military Training is plenty,—enroll me as a member. Here's my
contribution," one college has
did not like the
answered.
working of the S. A. T. C., but
we like this less."
An expression of opposition is
being signed by many Hopkins
men at the post office, and a protest was voiced at Friday's mass
At first sight the
meeting.
"Union" appears to be unworthy
even of such notice—an organization whose literature should
promptly be consigned to the
basket. When we consider, however, that it has operated for four
years, is active in Congress, furnishes a confidential bulletin service to members, and maintains
a strong press bureau, we can see
a menace to the safety of our
country. It would be well then
for colleges—and several have already done so—to make a signed
demonstration that no such
propaganda can gain ground
among American college men.

STUDENTS OBJECT TO "AMERICAN
UNION AGAINST MILITARISM."

A very enthusiastic mass meeting was held in the Civil Engineering hall on Friday, May 2.
The meeting was opened by a
short talk by Harris Kirk, president of the student council, who
explained the action which the
council had taken to discourage
the spreading of the propaganda
of the American Union Against
Militarism, which has been so
freely distributed among the colleges and universities of this country. The object of this "Union" is
to abolish all forms of military
training, especially the R. 0. T. C.
The purpose of and forces behind
such a movement as this are
plainly Bolshevik. After a few
words from Captain Guild, the
following protest against the
Union was unanimously adopted:
To the War Department:
The undersigned students of
this University desire to express
their disapproval of the activities of the "American Union
Against Militarism," as expressed
by the pamphlets and post cards
sent out by this "Union."
A copy of this protest is now
at the University post-office, and
all students are urged to sign it
at once.
Announcements were then made
by the Dramatic Club and other
organizations, and the meeting
was closed by a number of peppy
yells and songs, led by the newly
elected leaders, Townsend and
Lovell.

Urges Greater Support for Teams.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir:—Now that the baseball
season is in full sway it seems
to me that more attention should
be called to the cheering. Nearly
one half of the under-graduate
students appear to have the idea
that attending this university involves. nothing more than applying themselves to their various

courses. I do not mean to insinuate that this is not by far
their most important duty, but at
the same time I wish to emphasize that it is up to every student to be out for some college
activity.
If you can't make the team, at
least come out and root for it.
Give it the benefit of all the "pep"
and enthusiasm that is in you.
Let it know that there is a• big
crowd of followers in the stand
watching its every movement, and
let it know it by the noise you
make. At all our games this
year we have had a fair number
of rooters on hand, but there
ought to have been twice as many
and I want to take this opportunity to urge every man to come
out for every game and cheer his
team to victory.

ROOTER.

117th VICTIM OF 'VARSITY NINE

MURPHY ADDRESSES STUDENTS

Mortarmen Give Black and Blue a Scare
but Fail to Hit Judefind —Littman,
Sharretts, E. Jones, and Judefind
Star with Willow for Hopkins.

Coach Tells How Recent Athletic
Achievements of J. H. U. Teams Have
Paved Way for Bigger Athletic Relations-Freshmen to carry Banner.

Coming up from behind, the
baseball team nosed out the 117th
Trench Mortar Battery, 9-8.
Calkins, a new addition to the
squad, started the game on the
peak, but proved to be unsteady,
and was yanked after four runs
had been scored in the fourth.
Judefind was sent in to carry on
the twirling, and allowed only
three scattered hits.
In the meantime the Black and
Blue batters had no difficulty in
solving Wasserman's delivery,
hitting the ball at will and scoring in every session but one. The
Battery started off with a jump,
denting the rubber three times in
the first session on four passes
and three errors. The 'Varsity
came back at them with a like
number of counters in its turn.
Benson was out, Gerwig to
Wright. Littman singled to left
and Sharretts knocked a grounder
to short that was too hot to handle. Kolhep then made a wild
heave to first, and Littman
crossed the plate. Knecht sacrificed Sharretts to third, the latter
scoring on a wild throw by the
second baseman.
Bloomsburg
walked, stole second and counted
when Yarnell dropped Jack Jones'
fly.
A pass, an error, and three
triples accounted for a quartet
of tallies garnered by the mortarmen in the fourth. Hopkins
tied the count in the sixth, but
the overseas men forged ahead in
the seventh on a single, a pass
and an error. Iii the last half
Elmer Jones led off with a double to left, but hurt his foot, so
Webb was sent in to run for
him. Egerton flied to Wright.
Then Judefind came to bat and
won his own game by singling to
right, driving Webb in with the
tying count, and scoring a moment later on Sharretts' single.
The score:

A mass meeting was called on
April 29, 1919, before the baseball game with the 117th Trench
Mortar Battery. In spite of the
short notice given, the meeting
was well attended, and was
marked by announcements of
general interest to Hopkins students.
Harris Kirk started things by
urging everyone to attend the
game in the afternoon, and announced that there would be a
mass meeting every Friday, at 1
o'clock, at which everyone was expected to be present—no exceptions.
Coach Murphy then said that
he wanted to see the Trench Mortarmen given a good reception at
Homewood Field. Charlie Leber
led some Hopkins songs and yells
which were delivered with the
same old pep. Then a call for
volunteers went forth — volunteers to carry in the 117th's
parade the banner announcing
the game, and now it was that
our fine sense of modesty was
displayed. Call after call for
courageous volunteers was made
but still the bashful boys hung
back. It was even hinted that
a selective service act would have
to be put into action and the required number drafted from the
freshman. Finally four brave
youths of '22 stood up and the
danger was over.
The meeting wound up with an
interesting announcement by Mr.
Murphy. This was about the
University's entrance into big
league relations. During its
northern trip, the baseball team
defeated Columbia, whose team
in turn trounced Princeton.
This, of course, made a good
impression on some of the larger
universities. Moreover, at the
Penn Relays in Philadelphia, the
J. H. U. track men carried off a
banner and broke a record. At
this meet teams from three Baltimore institutions won their

VIRGINIA AWARDED DECISION
University of Virginia Downs Hopkins
Debaters by Vote of 2-1—Rebuttal
Speeches Fast and Furious-Hopkins
Entertained at Charlottesville.

You may hunt the
world over—but you cannot find a cigarette to
take the place of Murad.
The tobacco in Murad is 100% pure
Turkish—and Turkish is the most
famous of all tobaccos for cigarettes.
It is true that “ordinary" cigarettes

"Judge for yourself

At Charlottesville the Black
and Blue team was defeated by
the Virginia affirmative, the
judges voting two to one in favor
of the latter. Messrs. Foster and
Lavenstein, the'Virginia debaters,
were forced to go full steam the
whole way; for it was one of the
closest debates the triangle has
had. It was give and take from
start to finish; the rebuttals
ended up in a veritable whirlwind on each side.
The Hopkins team was shown
all the attentions and courtesies
which the Charlottevillians, in
true chivalrous southern style,
could shower upon them. Before
the debate, the Hopkins men were
shown the beauties of the University which Jefferson founded.
In the evening, after the contest,
an entertainment was provided,
in which debaters and audience
joined.

1Rare Instrument in Botanical Gardens.
A dendrograph has been installed on a beech tree located in
the north end of the botanical
garden back of Gilman Hall.
The dendrograph, a late invention by Dr. MacDougal of the
Desert Laboratory, Arizona, is an
instrument which records the
daily expansion and contraction
of a tree trunk. The data thus
recorded is to be used in the
study of the growth of trees.

According to a recent University notice, during the month of
May in each year all students in
residence must consult their advisers with regard to the courses
to be taken in the following
academic year, and must report
to the Registrar before June 1st.
A fine of one dollar a day will
be levied for delay in making
this report. Changes may be
made by notification to the Registrar at any time before September 24, 1919; after that date,
only with the approval of the
Dean. Students who fail to attend courses selected, or Who
drop courses without the approval of the Dean, will be
marked absent and will be subject to the regulations of the
Committee on Absences.
A
printed form is provided for the
report of courses.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 6, 1919

DR. SLONIMSKY ADDRESSES CLUB

JUNIORS ELECT HULLABALOO
EDITOR FOR NEXT YEAR.

Speaks at Second Meeting of Social
Science Club on "An Indictment
of the Present Social Order."

At a meeting of the Junior
class on May 1st it was- decided
to depart from the custom of
previous years and elect the
Editor-in-Chief of the 1920 Hullabaloo, by the vote of the class.
Millard Foard and John Bartels
were nominated for this respons
ible position, and, on the declining of the honor by the latter,
Foard was elected by acclamation.
The question as to whom the
class would invite to the Junior
banquet to represent the faculty
was likewise voted upon. After
sonic discussion, Professor Julian
C. Smallwood, beloved by all of
the engineering students, was
chosen.
The election of the other four
members of the Hullabaloo board
was postponed until the next
meeting.

At the second meeting of the
Social Science Club, Dr. Slonimsky spoke on the first of the subjects set by the club for discussion, namely, on "The Indictment of the Present Social Order." His main contention was
that the root cause of the evils
of society is not to be sought in
any one single wrong or defect,
economic or political in character,
but rather in the method underlying both, the basic method of
the present social order. This
he designated as the "jungle
method," or the method of decision through superior force, and
he pointed out that it is not
merely inhuman' but enormously
wasteful.
Dr. Slonimsky said in part:
"The method by which society
lives is one taken over from a
lower plane of life. The method
of the jungle was fitted for the
jungle, but on the human plane
it is an absurd and deadly survival, which must be replaced by
the method of intelligent co-operation.• As long as we continue to
live by it, nothing permanently
progressive can be achieved. It
gives the lie to all our professions of religion, morality and
civilization; and it cramps and
distorts human nature, and nullifies its best endeavors. Thus, under the present system even the
most well-intentioned capitalist,
the most idealistic statesman, are
condemned to futility. Should
the young capitalist go too far
in his attempts to help his employees, he would be pushed to
the wall by the ruthless competition of his next door neighbor.
Should the young statesman be
utterly free from imperialistic
greed, should he be actuated by
nothing but pure love for his own
country, he would still be compelled by the logic of circumstances to urge adequate armament in self-defense, and thus
bring on militarism and all that
it implies. The effective morality
of individuals can hardly rise
higher than that of the system in
which they live. Those who are
unwilling to work for a better
order rest their arguments upon
'human nature' and its inherent
selfishness and aggressiveness.
War and poverty would accordingly be a part of the eternal
scheme of things. That is not
merely a counsel of despair but
also one of ignorance. In the
first place, human nature is quite
as much social and altruistic as
it is selfish and domineering;
only that by our system we allow
the latter to flourish and compel
the former to wither. In the second place, human nature is not
the hard and fast entity imagined; it is a bundle of possi-

RED EAGLE STICKMEN DEFEAT
POLYTECHNIC BY 8-6 SCORE.

After having tied Poly in a
previous game, the Red Eagles
gained a victory Wednesday by a
score of 8-6. At the very first,
the Eagles took the lead, and
were not hard pressed at any
time'. during the game. Poly
scored two in the last five minutes. For Hopkins Blum and
Barrett starred, while Norris and
Melanet played well for Poly.
